name: clean_backend

logFailedRequest.name: logFailedRequest
logFailedRequest.comment: Returns a function, which processes request using clean_backend/clean_backend.logFailedRequest.processRequest, and if processing fails, request details are logged.

parseCookieString.name: parseCookieString
parseCookieString.comment: Parse string value encoded by clean_backend/clean_backend.toCookieString method and return originaly encoded object.

toCookieString.name: toCookieString
toCookieString.comment: Convert any JSON encodable clean_backend/clean_backend.toCookieString.value to cookie-safe string value as specified by RFC 6265.

class.name: Backend
class.preview: A wrapper for clean_backend/dart:io.HttpServer, handles clean_backend/dart:io.HttpRequests. Provides convenient addition of clean_backend/dart:io.HttpRequest handlers per route. Manages routing requests to proper routes internally.

class.name: Request
class.preview: Simple wrapper for important parts of clean_backend/dart:io.HttpRequest, clean_backend/dart:io.HttpResponse, clean_backend/dart:io.HttpHeaders and matched parameters from path

class.name: ZonedRequestNavigator
class.preview: Works just like clean_backend/clean_backend.RequestNavigator, except that its handlers are wrapped in a clean_backend/dart:async.Zone, and some additional logs.

packageIntro:
Backend server for convenient request handling

Motivation

Have you ever tried to work with HttpServer ? It's just a stream of HttpRequests, all going to this single location, where you would have to handle them differently based on their URI, manage cookies, handle cases when URI is invalid...and all this on your own. This just makes your life much easier.

What is it good for ?

Basically, it is a HttpServer, which supports adding Request handlers per path and manages cookies conveniently. This Request is a special class, which wraps the imporant parts of the whole request together. It's just as simple as adding a new Route path associated with some name and then adding a Request handler for this route's name. Route paths support parameters, which are then accessible in the Request object in handler. Additionally, all requests - failed or not, are logged with duration of the process.
